com.cloudpos

Class DeviceException

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Throwable
      • java.lang.Exception
        • com.cloudpos.DeviceException
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable

    public class DeviceException
extends java.lang.Exception
    An DeviceException is thrown when access problems are detected by the service controls.

    This is a lightweight class. It is expected that its objects will be created dynamically and discarded after use, even in a resource-constrained environment. It therefore has no "set" method for the field used to identify the cause of the exception; that member must be set by the constructor when the object is created.

    Each access exception has a code associated with it, indicating the reason for the exception. See the descriptions of the codes for details of the contexts in which each code may occur.

    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Field Detail

      • BAD_CONTROL_MODE

        public static final int BAD_CONTROL_MODE
        The device object is not in the proper mode to request this action. This code is used in the following situations:
        • If open() is called when the control is already open.
        • If any method except open() is called when the control is not open.
        • Some controls use this for other situations in which some method calls are allowed only when the control is in a particular state. See the specifications of particular controls for details of these.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • NO_IMPLEMENT

        public static final int NO_IMPLEMENT
        the device doesn't support the request will use this code.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • REQUEST_PENDING

        public static final int REQUEST_PENDING
        A previous request through this device object has not been completed. This code is used in the following situations:
        • If any method is called when another asynchronous operation is pending.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • NO_REQUEST_PENDING

        public static final int NO_REQUEST_PENDING
        No request was pending when cancelRequest() was invoked. This code is only used by cancelRequest methods.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • NO_PERMISSION

        public static final int NO_PERMISSION
        A basic Android application has no permissions associated with it by default, meaning it can not do anything that would adversely impact the user experience or any data on the device.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values
